elements.content: The reactions of the unsymmetrical ligand N-phenyl-N′-cyano-formamidine (L) with AgX (X = NO3 −, SO3CF3 −, and BF4 −) afforded the complexes [AgL 3NO3] (1), [AgLSO3CF3]∞ (2) and [AgLBF4]∞ (3), whereas the reactions of L with AgClO4 in tetrahydrofuran at room temperature and at refluxing temperature afforded two supramolecular isomers of [AgLClO4]∞, (4) and (5), respectively. These complexes were characterized by X-ray crystallography, which confirmed that complexes 2−5 are coordination polymers. Complex 1 is a triangular planar molecule with three L’s coordinating to the Ag(I) metal center through the cyano nitrogen atoms. While the cations of complexes 2−4 form one-dimensional zigzag chains, those of 5 show helical chains that are interlinked through η3 π-donor behavior of the unsymmetrical ligand L to form two-dimensional polymeric sheets. The L ligands in complex 1 adopt the syn conformation, and those in 2–5 adopt the anti conformation.

elements.content: A series of Ag(I) complexes of the type [AgL 3NO3] (L = N-phenyl-N’-cyano-formamidine) (1), [AgLSO3CF3]∞ (2), [AgLBF4]∞ (3), and two supramolecular isomers of [AgLClO4]∞ (4) and (5) are reported. Complex 1 is a triangular planar molecule with three L’s coordinating to the Ag(I) metal center through the cyano nitrogen atoms. While the cations of complexes 2−4 form one-dimensional (1D) zigzag chains, those of 5 show helical chains that are interlinked through η3 π-donor behavior of the unsymmetrical ligand L to form two-dimensional (2D) polymeric sheets.

elements.content: The design and synthesis of functional coordination polymers have been of interest in recent years. These new complexes thus synthesized are widely regarded as promising materials for application in catalysis, magnet, semiconductor and optics. The range and variety of self-assembling inorganic structures that can be constructed rely on the presence of suitable metal–ligand interactions and supramolecular contacts, that is, hydrogen bondings and other weak interactions.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The design and synthesis of functional coordination polymers have been of interest in recent years. These new complexes thus synthesized are widely regarded as promising materials for application in catalysis, magnet, semiconductor and optics. The range and variety of self-assembling inorganic structures that can be constructed rely on the presence of suitable metal-ligand interactions and supramolecular contacts, that is, hydrogen bondings and other weak interactions.

elements.content: The coordination networks of metal complexes containing flexible bidentate ligands are less predictable due to the possible occurrence of supramolecular isomerism involving the adoption of different ligand conformations. It is recognized that the ligand 1,2-bis(4-pyridyl)ethane can adopt either a gauche or anti geometry, whereas the flexible ligand 1,3-bis(4-pyridyl)propane can exist in anti−anti, gauche−anti, and gauche–gauche conformations. The structural types of the resulting coordination polymers are also affected by factors such as counterion, metal-to-ligand ratio, and solvent.
elements.clean_text: The coordination networks of metal complexes containing flexible bidentate ligands are less predictable due to the possible occurrence of supramolecular isomerism involving the adoption of different ligand conformations. It is recognized that the ligand 1,2-bis(4-pyridyl)ethane can adopt either a gauche or anti geometry, whereas the flexible ligand 1,3-bis(4-pyridyl)propane can exist in anti-anti, gauche-anti, and gauche-gauche conformations. The structural types of the resulting coordination polymers are also affected by factors such as counterion, metal-to-ligand ratio, and solvent.

elements.content: We are currently exploring the roles of ligand conformations in the structural types. Recently, we have reported a series of one-dimensional (1D) Ag(I) coordination polymers containing a new flexible ligand N,N′-di(2-pyridyl)adipoamide). The GAG trans, AAA trans, GGG cis, and AGA cis conformations were found, which also differ in the dihedral angle between the two pyridyl rings. We now report the chemistry of the Ag(I) complexes containing the unsymmetrical formamidine ligand N-phenyl-N′-cyano-formamidine, L. While the coordination chemistry of formamidine compounds has been investigated extensively and many efforts have been concentrated on the abilities of their anions to form bridges between metal atoms, none of the Ag(I) coordination polymers have been reported to contain the neutral formamidine ligands. The syntheses, structures, and ligand conformations of Ag(I) complexes of the types [AgL 3NO3] (1), [AgLSO3CF3]∞ (2), [AgLBF4]∞ (3), and two temperature-dependent supramolecular isomers of [AgLClO4]∞ (4) and (5) form the subject of this report.

elements.content: All manipulations were carried out under dry, oxygen-free nitrogen by using Schlenk techniques, unless otherwise noted. Solvents were dried and deoxygenated by refluxing over the appropriate reagents before use. Elemental analyses were obtained from a PE 2400 series II CHNS/O analyzer or a HERAEUS VaruoEL analyzer. IR spectra (KBr disk) were recorded on a Jasco FT/IR-460 plus spectrometer. Emission spectra were obtained from Hitachi F-4500 spectrometer. Differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) measurements were carried on a Dupon DSC Q-10.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

General Procedures

All manipulations were carried out under dry, oxygen-free nitrogen by using Schlenk techniques, unless otherwise noted. Solvents were dried and deoxygenated by refluxing over the appropriate reagents before use. Elemental analyses were obtained from a PE 2400 series II CHNS/O analyzer or a HERAEUS VaruoEL analyzer. IR spectra (KBr disk) were recorded on a Jasco FT/IR-460 plus spectrometer. Emission spectra were obtained from Hitachi F-4500 spectrometer. Differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) measurements were carried on a Dupon DSC Q-10.

elements.content: The reagent N-phenyl-N′-cyano-formamidine was purchased from Acros Chemical Co., silver nitrate was from Wako Chemical Co., silver tetrafluoborate was from Aldrich Chemical Co., and silver perchlorate and silver trifluoromethane sulfonate were from Strem Chemical Co. Caution: Perchlorate salts are dangerous (especially if they are dry) and should be handled with care.
elements.clean_text:
Materials

The reagent N-phenyl-N'-cyano-formamidine was purchased from Acros Chemical Co., silver nitrate was from Wako Chemical Co., silver tetrafluoborate was from Aldrich Chemical Co., and silver perchlorate and silver trifluoromethane sulfonate were from Strem Chemical Co. Caution: Perchlorate salts are dangerous (especially if they are dry) and should be handled with care.

elements.content: L (0.43 g, 3.0 mmol) was placed in a flask containing 15 mL of CH3CN, and AgNO3 (0.17 g, 1.0 mmol) was added. The mixture was then refluxed for 4 h and allowed to cool to room temperature to afford a colorless solution. The solution was filtered, and then diethylether was added to introduce precipitate. The precipitate was filtered and washed by diethyl ether (2 × 10 mL) and then dried under vacuum to give the white product. Colorless crystals were obtained by slow diffusion of ether into a CH3CN solution of the compound. Several different M to L ratios (1:1, 1:2, and 1:3) were tried to prepare 1, which afforded the same structure with different yields, indicating that the stoichiometry of 1 is independent of the metal-to-ligand ratio. Attempts to perform the experiment in tetrahydrofuran (THF) led to the formation of an insoluble solid. Yield: 0.45 g (74% based on Ag). Anal. Calcd. for C24H21AgN10O3 (MW = 605.38): C, 47.62; H, 3.50; N, 23.14%; Found: C, 47.59; H, 3.13; N, 23.58%. IR (cm−1): 3272(m), 3146(m), 3025(m), 2198(s), 1637(s), 1617(s), 1590(s), 1569(s), 1493(m), 1452(m), 1347(s), 1061(w), 901(w) 832(w), 796(w), 753(m), 682(m), 606(w), 559(w), 491(w).

elements.content: Complexes 1–5 were prepared under N2-atmosphere to prevent air-sensitivity of the products during reactions. They were moderately air-sensitive both in solution and in solid states and should be kept under N2. They were not light-sensitive.

elements.content: The diffraction data of 1−5 were collected at 22 °C on a Bruker AXS P4 diffractomer which is equipped with a graphite-monochromated MoKα (λα = 0.71073 Å) radiation and a 1.0 mm beam collimator. Data reduction was performed by standard methods with the use of well-established computational procedures. A colorless crystal of 1 was mounted on the top of a glass fiber with epoxy cement in normal atmosphere. ω data collection method was used to scan the data points at 5.70° ≤ 2θ ≤ 50.00°. The structure factors were obtained after Lorentz and polarization correction. The positions of some of the heavier atoms, including the silver atom, were located by the direct method. The remaining atoms were found in a series of alternating difference Fourier maps and least-square refinements. Final residuals of the final refinement were R 1 = 0.0286 and wR 2 = 0.0625. The crystallographic procedures for the other complexes were similar to those for 1. The space group C2/c has been tested for 1 but did not lead to a reasonable result. Since only small fractions of Friedel pairs were collected prior to the space group determination, a low data-to-parameter ratio resulted. Basic information pertaining to crystal parameters and structure refinement are summarized in Table . Selected bond distances and angles are listed in Table . Crystallographic data (CIF files, excluding structure factors) for 1−5 have been deposited with the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre, CCDC no. 643236 (1), 643237 (2), 643238 (3), 630692 (4), 630693 (5).

X-ray Crystallography

The diffraction data of 1-5 were collected at 22 °C on a Bruker AXS P4 diffractomer which is equipped with a graphite-monochromated MoKα (λα = 0.71073 Å) radiation and a 1.0 mm beam collimator. Data reduction was performed by standard methods with the use of well-established computational procedures. A colorless crystal of 1 was mounted on the top of a glass fiber with epoxy cement in normal atmosphere. ω data collection method was used to scan the data points at 5.70° ≤ 2θ ≤ 50.00°. The structure factors were obtained after Lorentz and polarization correction. The positions of some of the heavier atoms, including the silver atom, were located by the direct method. The remaining atoms were found in a series of alternating difference Fourier maps and least-square refinements. Final residuals of the final refinement were R 1 = 0.0286 and wR 2 = 0.0625. The crystallographic procedures for the other complexes were similar to those for 1. The space group C2/c has been tested for 1 but did not lead to a reasonable result. Since only small fractions of Friedel pairs were collected prior to the space group determination, a low data-to-parameter ratio resulted. Basic information pertaining to crystal parameters and structure refinement are summarized in Table . Selected bond distances and angles are listed in Table . Crystallographic data (CIF files, excluding structure factors) for 1-5 have been deposited with the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre, CCDC no. 643236 (1), 643237 (2), 643238 (3), 630692 (4), 630693 (5).

The structure of complex 1 was solved in the space group Cc, and Figure a shows its molecular structure. Complex 1 is a three-coordinate complex in which three neutral formamidine ligands are each bonded via the nitrogen atom of the cyano group (Ag−N(1) = 2.191(5), Ag−N(4) = 2.242(5), Ag−N(7) = 2.181(5)). The silver metal adopts a triangular planar geometry with the bond angles close to 120° and is located only 0.036 Å out of the plane defined by the three nitrogen atoms coordinated to the metal atom. Complex 1 makes an interesting comparison with the three-coordinate complex Ag(HDphF)2(OSO2CH3) which was prepared from the reaction of AgSO3CF3 with HDphF (HDphF = N,N′-diphenylformamidine). The silver atom in Ag(HDphF)2(OSO2CF3) is bonded to two nitrogen atoms, each to one neutral formamidine ligand, and weakly coordinated to the triflate anion through an oxygen atom. In marked contrast to 1, the AgN2O group is significantly distorted from planar with an N−Ag−N angle of 142.3(2)° and O−Ag−N angles of 122.4(2) and 92.0(1)°. The packing diagram of 1 (Figure b) shows that the NO3 − anion are interacted with the cations through extensive N−H---O hydrogen bonds [(N---O = 2.852(2)−3.409(6) ] and weak C−H---O hydrogen bonds [C---O = 3.365(7)−3.450(5)], forming 2D pleated molecular sheets which are also interacted through π−π stacking interactions. The distance between the two phenyl rings in the π−π stacking interactions (Figure c) is 3.82 Å (typical cutoff distance 3.9).

Complex 1 makes an interesting comparison with the three-coordinate complex Ag(HDphF)2(OSO2CH3) which was prepared from the reaction of AgSO3CF3 with HDphF (HDphF = N,N'-diphenylformamidine). elements.content: Complex 2 was solved in the space group P21/c. Figure a shows the molecular structure of 2. The silver atom is bonded to one amine nitrogen (Ag−N(1) = 2.264(4) Å) and one cyano nitrogen atoms (Ag−N(3A) = 2.162(5) Å) of different L ligands to form 1D zigzag chains. The silver atom is also bonded to one oxygen atom of the anion (Ag−O(1) = 2.541(5) Å) to complete the distorted T-shaped coordination geometry. It is noted that the typical range of Ag−O bonds is 2.3–2.6 Å. Noticeably, these 1D chains are stacked together in a ABAB fashion (Figure c). The cationic chains are interlinked by CF3SO3 − anions through Ag---O (Ag---O = 2.797(8) Å and 2.879(7) Å) interactions and weak C−H---O (C---O = 3.264(1)−3.357(14) Å) hydrogen bonds. The Ag---O distance is significantly shorter than their van der Waals contact of 3.24 Å (van der Waals radius for Ag = 1.72 and O = 1.52 Å).

elements.content: Complexes 3 and 4 are isomorphous and were solved in the same space group Pca21. Figure a shows a representative molecular diagram for 4. The structure of 3 is similar to that of 4 where the ClO4 − anion is replaced by BF4 − anion. The silver metal center is coordinated to one cyano nitrogen (Ag−N(1) = 2.133(6) Å for 3 and 2.140(7) Å for 4) and one amine nitrogen atom (Ag−N(2A) = 2.218(5) Å for 3 and 2.231(6) Å for 4) of two different L ligands to form a distorted linear geometry (N(1)−Ag−N(2A) = 172.8(2)° for 3 and 174.3(2)° for 4). Complexes 3 and 4 form zigzag chains that are interlinked by BF4 − and ClO4 − anions through Ag---F [Ag---F = 2.666(2) Å] interactions and N−H---F [N---F = 2.972(1)−3.303(1) Å] hydrogen bonds and weak C−H---F [C---F = 3.030(1)−3.312(1) Å] hydrogen bonds for 3, and, similarly, through Ag---O [Ag---O = 2.654(2) and 2.975(3) Å] interactions and weak N−H---O [N---O = 3.012(1) and 3.383(2) Å] hydrogen bond and weak C−H---O [C---O = 3.012(2)−3.294(2) Å] hydrogen bond for 4, respectively. The Ag---F distance is significantly shorter than their van der Waals contact of 3.19 Å (van der Waals radius for Ag = 1.72 and F = 1.47 Å). The packing diagram of 4 is depicted in Figure b.

elements.content: The structure of 5 was solved in the space group P21/n. A view of the asymmetric of 5 is shown in Figure a. In marked contrast to 4, the ClO4 − anions in 5 are coordinated to the silver metal atoms [Ag−O(1) = 2.422(6) Å] (Figure b). The silver atoms are bridged by the L ligands [Ag−N(1A) = 2.172(7) Å, Ag−N(2) = 2.389(6) Å], forming 1D helical chains with a period of 7.615 Å. In addition, each silver atom is also coordinated by three phenyl carbon atoms [Ag−C(5B) = 2.816(19), Ag−C(6B) = 2.507(7), and Ag−C(7B) = 2.871(3) Å] of a different L ligand. Since these Ag−C distances are below the upper limit of 2.92 Å for effective π interaction between silver(I) and an aryl carbon atom, the coordination mode can be regarded as η3. Because the Ag−C distances approach to the upper limit, no significant geometric distortion of the aryl group is observed. The largest deviation of C-atom from the ring is 0.0069 Å and the average deviation is 0.0038 Å. Noticeably, the Ag-η3-arene bondings subsequently link the 1D helical chains to form a 2D molecular sheet (Figure c). Taking the η3-phenyl group as one ligand, the coordination geometry around Ag is best described as a distorted tetrahedral [N(1A)−Ag−N(2) = 126.3(2)°, N(1A)−Ag−O(1) = 111.7(3)°, N(2)−Ag−O(1) = 89.6(2)°].

elements.content: The interaction between cations and the π system of a ligand represents a possible driving force for the building of novel molecular architectures. More than 130 examples of Ag-η1- and Ag-η2-arene bonding have been found, with a mean Ag−arene distance of 2.82 Å. While there are several complexes in which the organic ligands function as η3 π donor, no η3 π donor has been found to link the 1D chains to form a 2D molecular sheet. The η3 π donor behavior of the benzyltrimethylammonium ion was observed in the polymeric silver(I) complex [(PhCH2NMe3)Ag7(C2)(CF3CO2)6] n , where the Ag(I) column is coordinated by the exterior silver(I)−aromatic interaction, and the Ag−C distances are 2.468, 2.784 and 2.878 Å. The silver atom in the molecule Ag{C6H4(CF3)2}Al(pftb)4] is weakly η3-coordinated by the carbon atoms of the 1,3-(CF3)2C6H4 molecule with Ag−C distances of 2.496(8), 2.596(7), and 3.005(8) Å. In the complex [Ag(GaCl4)·{(p-C6H4CH2CH2)2}], the silver atom in the molecule is η3-coordinated by the carbon atoms of the benzene rings of the 2,2-cyclophane to form a 1D linear chain, with Ag−C distances of 2.642(8), 2.431(7), and 2.661(8) Å.

More than 130 examples of Ag-η1- and Ag-η2-arene bonding have been found, with a mean Ag-arene distance of 2.82 Å. While there are several complexes in which the organic ligands function as η3 π donor, no η3 π donor has been found to link the 1D chains to form a 2D molecular sheet. The η3 π donor behavior of the benzyltrimethylammonium ion was observed in the polymeric silver(I) complex [(PhCH2NMe3)Ag7(C2)(CF3CO2)6] n , where the Ag(I) column is coordinated by the exterior silver(I)-aromatic interaction, and the Ag-C distances are 2.468, 2.784 and 2.878 Å. The silver atom in the molecule Ag{C6H4(CF3)2}Al(pftb)4] is weakly η3-coordinated by the carbon atoms of the 1,3-(CF3)2C6H4 molecule with Ag-C distances of 2.496(8), 2.596(7), and 3.005(8) Å. In the complex [Ag(GaCl4)⋅{(p-C6H4CH2CH2)2}], the silver atom in the molecule is η3-coordinated by the carbon atoms of the benzene rings of the 2,2-cyclophane to form a 1D linear chain, with Ag-C distances of 2.642(8), 2.431(7), and 2.661(8) Å.

elements.content: While supramolecular isomers have been the subject of several studies during recent years, most of them are not polymorphs −e for their different chemical compositions due to the coexistence of solvent or guest molecules to satisfy crystal packing. Among these polymorphs, those of Ag(im) (Him = imidazole) and [Ag2 L′(NO3)2] (L′ = 1,4-bis((cyclohexylthio)acetyl)piperazine) contain the Ag(I) metal centers. While the patterns of the superstructures of Ag(im) were attributed to the relative orientations of the im ligands, those of [Ag2 L′ (NO3)2] were to the solvent composition in crystallization. In this study two polymorphs of [AgLClO4]∞, (4) and (5), were obtained at room temperature and at refluxing temperature, respectively, in THF, which show different Ag+---OClO3 − distances. To check the bulk purity, we have measured the XRPD of complexes 4 and 5. As shown in Figures and , recorded and simulated XRPD patterns in both 4 and 5 are quite similar, confirming the bulk purity of these two polymorphs. We may therefore propose that the reaction of silver perchlorate with the formamidine ligand L at lower temperature afforded predominantly the 1D product 4, which is the kinetic product of the reaction, equilibrating to the thermodynamically more stable 2D product 5 at higher temperature. It is also noted that the T m values of complexes 4 and 5 have been measured by using differential scanning calorimetry (DSC), showing that the T m value of complex 5, 179 °C, is larger than that of complex 4, which is 168 °C.

elements.content: In complexes 2 and 5, the CF3SO3 − and ClO4 − anions are coordinated to the Ag(I) centers through the oxygen atom with different Ag−O distances of 2.541(5) and 2.422(6) Å, respectively, whereas the BF4 − and ClO4 − anions in 3 and 4 only interact with the Ag(I) metal centers through Ag---F [2.666 (2) Å] and Ag---O [2.654(2) Å] interactions, respectively. While the cations of 2–4 form zigzag chains, those of 5 are helical and are interlinked through Ag-η3−arene bondings to form a 2D molecular sheet, indicating that the Ag---O bond strength and the variability of the metal geometry play important roles in determining the structural type. The importance of the Ag---O interactions in determining the structure was seen in the pair of supramolecular isomers of [Ag2 L′ (NO3)2] (L′ = 1,4-bis((cyclohexylthio)acetyl)piperazine) which show 2D and three-dimensional (3D) frameworks, respectively. In the 2D form, the NO3 − anions are coordinated to the Ag(I) metal centers in a bidentate fashion through two oxygen atoms [Ag−O = 2.352(3) and 2.468(3) Å], whereas in the 3D form, the NO3 − anions are coordinated to the Ag(I) metal centers through only one oxygen atom [Ag−O = 2.356(2) Å].

Structural Comparisons

In complexes 2 and 5, the CF3SO3 - and ClO4 - anions are coordinated to the Ag(I) centers through the oxygen atom with different Ag-O distances of 2.541(5) and 2.422(6) Å, respectively, whereas the BF4 - and ClO4 - anions in 3 and 4 only interact with the Ag(I) metal centers through Ag---F [2.666 (2) Å] and Ag---O [2.654(2) Å] interactions, respectively. While the cations of 2-4 form zigzag chains, those of 5 are helical and are interlinked through Ag-η3-arene bondings to form a 2D molecular sheet, indicating that the Ag---O bond strength and the variability of the metal geometry play important roles in determining the structural type. The importance of the Ag---O interactions in determining the structure was seen in the pair of supramolecular isomers of [Ag2 L' (NO3)2] (L' = 1,4-bis((cyclohexylthio)acetyl)piperazine) which show 2D and three-dimensional (3D) frameworks, respectively. In the 2D form, the NO3 - anions are coordinated to the Ag(I) metal centers in a bidentate fashion through two oxygen atoms [Ag-O = 2.352(3) and 2.468(3) Å], whereas in the 3D form, the NO3 - anions are coordinated to the Ag(I) metal centers through only one oxygen atom [Ag-O = 2.356(2) Å].

A conformational descriptor for diarylformamidine bearing an m-alkoxy substituent has been proposed by Ren and coauthors and three stable conformations anticipated for anionic diarylformamidine, which were defined as (a) s-cis,s-cis- (s-cis-/s-trans- are defined between the N−C (methine) bond and the ring C−C bond prioritized by the OR group), (b) s-cis,s-trans-, and (c) s-trans,s-trans-. For neutral formamidine ligands, we have modified this descriptor and used syn and anti to indicate the relative positions of the methine and amine hydrogen atoms. Eight possible conformations for the neutral dipyridylformamidine ligands were proposed. The syn and anti designations are appropriate for the unsymmetrical neutral formamidine ligand N-phenyl-N′-cyano-formamidine, L, which correspond to the absolute value of the C−N−C−N torsion angle (θ) of 0 ≤ θ < 90° and 180 ≥ θ > 90°, respectively, Scheme . As shown in Table , while the three L ligands in 1 adopt the syn conformation, all the L ligands in 2–5 show the anti conformation. While the anti conformations are required for the L ligands to bridge the Ag atoms to form zigzag and helical chains in 2–4 and 5, respectively, the adoption of syn conformation for the L ligands in 1 is presumably due to the formation of the C−H---O and N−H---O hydrogen bonds to the oxygen atoms of the NO3 − anion. The triangular shape of the NO3 − anion may also play an important role in determining the ligand formation and the structural type.
elements.clean_text: A conformational descriptor for diarylformamidine bearing an m-alkoxy substituent has been proposed by Ren and coauthors and three stable conformations anticipated for anionic diarylformamidine, which were defined as (a) s-cis,s-cis- (s-cis-/s-trans- are defined between the N-C (methine) bond and the ring C-C bond prioritized by the OR group), (b) s-cis,s-trans-, and (c) s-trans,s-trans-. For neutral formamidine ligands, we have modified this descriptor and used syn and anti to indicate the relative positions of the methine and amine hydrogen atoms. Eight possible conformations for the neutral dipyridylformamidine ligands were proposed. The syn and anti designations are appropriate for the unsymmetrical neutral formamidine ligand N-phenyl-N'-cyano-formamidine, L, which correspond to the absolute value of the C-N-C-N torsion angle (θ) of 0 ≤ θ < 90° and 180 ≥ θ > 90°, respectively, Scheme . As shown in Table , while the three L ligands in 1 adopt the syn conformation, all the L ligands in 2-5 show the anti conformation. While the anti conformations are required for the L ligands to bridge the Ag atoms to form zigzag and helical chains in 2-4 and 5, respectively, the adoption of syn conformation for the L ligands in 1 is presumably due to the formation of the C-H---O and N-H---O hydrogen bonds to the oxygen atoms of the NO3 - anion. The triangular shape of the NO3 - anion may also play an important role in determining the ligand formation and the structural type.

elements.content: The IR spectrum of the free ligand L shows a sharp absorption at 2196 cm−1 for the C≡N stretch, while that of 1 shows absorption at 2199 cm−1 and those of 2−5 show absorption at 2198 cm−1, respectively, which are significantly lower than those of aliphatic nitriles which are in the range 2240–2260 cm−1, indicating the C≡N group in electronic conjugation with the formamidine group of the L ligand. This proposition can be verified by the fact that the three C−N distances to the formamidine nitrogen atoms in complexes 1–5 (Table ) are all similar. The similar IR wavenumbers for the C≡N groups in complexes 1–5 also indicate that the C≡N stretch is independent of the structural types.
elements.clean_text:
IR Spectra and Luminescent Properties

The IR spectrum of the free ligand L shows a sharp absorption at 2196 cm-1 for the C≡N stretch, while that of 1 shows absorption at 2199 cm-1 and those of 2-5 show absorption at 2198 cm-1, respectively, which are significantly lower than those of aliphatic nitriles which are in the range 2240-2260 cm-1, indicating the C≡N group in electronic conjugation with the formamidine group of the L ligand. This proposition can be verified by the fact that the three C-N distances to the formamidine nitrogen atoms in complexes 1-5 (Table ) are all similar. The similar IR wavenumbers for the C≡N groups in complexes 1-5 also indicate that the C≡N stretch is independent of the structural types.

elements.content: The luminescent spectra of complexes 1−5 as well as L were measured in the solid at room temperature (Figure ). Complexes 1−5 emit at λmax = 391, 393, 394, 392, and 393 nm, respectively, upon excitation at 245 nm, which are similar to that of L (395 nm). It is noted that the structural types hardly change the emission energies of these complexes, and hence the emission bands may be tentatively assigned as intraligand (IL) π → π* transitions.
elements.clean_text: The luminescent spectra of complexes 1-5 as well as L were measured in the solid at room temperature (Figure ). Complexes 1-5 emit at λmax = 391, 393, 394, 392, and 393 nm, respectively, upon excitation at 245 nm, which are similar to that of L (395 nm). It is noted that the structural types hardly change the emission energies of these complexes, and hence the emission bands may be tentatively assigned as intraligand (IL) π → π* transitions.

elements.content: In this study, the coordination chemistry of a flexible ligand N-phenyl-N′-cyano-formamidine (L) with Ag(I) salts was investigated. Complexes 2–5 are the first Ag(I) coordination polymers containing neutral formamidine ligands. While the L’s in 1 adopt the syn conformation to form a discrete molecule, those in 2–5 adopt the anti conformation to form coordination polymers. The L’s in 1–5 also show different dihedral angles between the two phenyl rings of two L ligands coordinated to the Ag(I) metal centers. Obviously, the ligand L is sufficiently flexible to adjust to the stereochemical requirements for the formation of the complexes 1–5. Owning to the variable coordination geometry of the Ag(I) metal center and the multidentate behavior of the L ligand, the different strengths in Ag+---OClO3 − interactions have resulted in a rare pair of polymorphs of a fixed stoichiometry with 1D and 2D structures, respectively. The Ag(I)---η3 π interaction in complex 5 links the 1D helical chains to form 2D molecular sheets. We also learn from this study that the flexibility of the spacer ligand as well as the coordination ability of the counterion and the variability of the metal geometry are essential in determining the structural type.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In this study, the coordination chemistry of a flexible ligand N-phenyl-N'-cyano-formamidine (L) with Ag(I) salts was investigated. Complexes 2-5 are the first Ag(I) coordination polymers containing neutral formamidine ligands. While the L's in 1 adopt the syn conformation to form a discrete molecule, those in 2-5 adopt the anti conformation to form coordination polymers. The L's in 1-5 also show different dihedral angles between the two phenyl rings of two L ligands coordinated to the Ag(I) metal centers. Obviously, the ligand L is sufficiently flexible to adjust to the stereochemical requirements for the formation of the complexes 1-5. Owning to the variable coordination geometry of the Ag(I) metal center and the multidentate behavior of the L ligand, the different strengths in Ag+---OClO3 - interactions have resulted in a rare pair of polymorphs of a fixed stoichiometry with 1D and 2D structures, respectively. The Ag(I)---η3 π interaction in complex 5 links the 1D helical chains to form 2D molecular sheets. We also learn from this study that the flexibility of the spacer ligand as well as the coordination ability of the counterion and the variability of the metal geometry are essential in determining the structural type.

L (0.43 g, 3.0 mmol) was placed in a flask containing 15 mL of CH3CN, and AgNO3 (0.17 g, 1.0 mmol) was added. The mixture was then refluxed for 4 h and allowed to cool to room temperature to afford a colorless solution. The solution was filtered, and then diethylether was added to introduce precipitate. The precipitate was filtered and washed by diethyl ether (2 × 10 mL) and then dried under vacuum to give the white product. Colorless crystals were obtained by slow diffusion of ether into a CH3CN solution of the compound. Several different M to L ratios (1:1, 1:2, and 1:3) were tried to prepare 1, which afforded the same structure with different yields, indicating that the stoichiometry of 1 is independent of the metal-to-ligand ratio. Attempts to perform the experiment in tetrahydrofuran (THF) led to the formation of an insoluble solid. Yield: 0.45 g (74% based on Ag). Anal. Calcd. for C24H21AgN10O3 (MW = 605.38): C, 47.62; H, 3.50; N, 23.14%; Found: C, 47.59; H, 3.13; N, 23.58%.
